name: Mixed Conditionals
description: Use mixed conditionals combining different time references
examples: If I had studied harder (past), I would be a doctor now (present)
If I were rich (present), I would have bought that house (past)

name: Inversion after Negative Adverbs
description: Use inversion after negative adverbs for emphasis (never, rarely, seldom, hardly)
examples: Never have I seen such beauty
Rarely does he complain
Seldom had they visited

name: Inversion after Only
description: Use inversion after 'only' expressions for emphasis
examples: Only then did I understand
Only after leaving did he realize
Only when stressed does she smoke

name: Advanced Relative Clauses
description: Use advanced relative structures (what, whereby, wherein, in which)
examples: What I need is a break
A process whereby we can improve
The city in which I was born

name: Reduced Relative Clauses
description: Use reduced relative clauses with participles
examples: The man standing there is my boss
People interested in art should visit
Tasks completed yesterday

name: Cleft Sentences - It
description: Use 'it' cleft sentences for emphasis
examples: It was John who told me
It's the price that matters
It was yesterday that I saw her

name: Cleft Sentences - What
description: Use 'what' cleft sentences for emphasis
examples: What I need is time
What she said was interesting
What matters is effort

name: Subjunctive Mood
description: Use subjunctive in formal contexts (suggest, demand, insist, it's important that)
examples: I suggest that he go
It's essential that she be present
They demanded that we leave

name: Advanced Conditionals - Unless, Provided, As long as
description: Use alternative conditional structures (unless, provided, as long as, in case)
examples: Unless you hurry, you'll be late
Provided you pay, you can stay
As long as it's cheap, I'll buy it

name: Future in the Past
description: Use 'would' and 'was going to' for future actions viewed from the past
examples: I knew she would call
He said he was going to resign
They told me it would rain

name: Modals - Past Speculation Advanced
description: Use advanced modal structures for past speculation and criticism (should have, ought to have, needn't have)
examples: You should have told me
He needn't have worried
They ought to have known better

name: Passive with Reporting Verbs
description: Use passive reporting structures (it is said, he is believed to, she is thought to)
examples: It is said that he is rich
He is believed to be innocent
She is thought to have left

name: Passive with Get
description: Use informal passive with 'get' (get hurt, get invited, get fired)
examples: He got hurt in the accident
I got invited to the party
She got promoted

name: Ellipsis and Substitution
description: Use ellipsis and substitution to avoid repetition (do so, do it, one, ones)
examples: I asked him to help and he did so
I need a pen. Do you have one?
She loves dancing and so do I

name: Emphatic Structures
description: Use emphatic structures with 'do/does/did' for emphasis
examples: I do like it (emphasis)
She did come (contrary to expectation)
They do work hard

name: Participle Clauses
description: Use participle clauses to provide additional information concisely
examples: Walking home, I saw an accident
Having finished, she left
Being tired, he went to bed

name: Nominalization
description: Transform verbs and adjectives into nouns for formal writing
examples: decide → decision
important → importance
develop → development
arrive → arrival

name: Distancing Language
description: Use distancing language for formal/academic writing (tend to, appear to, seem to)
examples: The data tend to suggest
It appears that
This seems to indicate

name: Vocabulary Set - Academic
description: Learn academic vocabulary for essays, research, analysis
examples: analyze, hypothesis, methodology, evidence, conclude, significant, criteria, factor, concept, theory

name: Vocabulary Set - Business
description: Learn business vocabulary for professional contexts
examples: revenue, profit, stakeholder, merger, budget, forecast, leverage, asset, liability, equity

name: Common Idioms
description: Understand and use common idioms in appropriate contexts
examples: break the ice, piece of cake, hit the nail on the head, cost an arm and a leg, under the weather

name: Collocations Advanced
description: Use advanced collocations naturally (adverb+adjective, verb+adverb)
examples: highly unlikely, utterly ridiculous, deeply concerned, fully aware, strongly recommend, readily available

name: Phrasal Verbs Advanced
description: Use advanced and less common phrasal verbs
examples: come across as, put up with, get away with, look down on, stand up for, live up to, come up with

name: Abstract Concepts Advanced
description: Discuss complex abstract ideas and philosophical concepts
examples: justice, morality, identity, consciousness, authenticity, existentialism, ideology, paradigm

name: Connotation and Register Awareness
description: Distinguish between words with similar meaning but different connotations and registers
examples: slim vs skinny, economical vs cheap, confident vs arrogant, residence vs house vs dwelling

name: Word Formation Advanced
description: Use prefixes, suffixes, and compounding to understand and create words
examples: un-, dis-, mis-, -ment, -tion, -ness, -ity, -able, -ive, overwork, breakdown

name: Writing Essays - Argumentative
description: Write well-structured argumentative essays with thesis, arguments, counterarguments (300-400 words)
examples: Thesis statement, arguments with evidence, counterarguments, rebuttal, conclusion

name: Writing Reports - Formal
description: Write formal reports with sections, data presentation, recommendations
examples: Executive summary, introduction, methodology, findings, analysis, recommendations, conclusion

name: Writing Articles
description: Write engaging articles for magazines, newspapers, websites with hook and conclusion
examples: Catchy title, engaging opening, main body, conclusion with impact

name: Writing Proposals
description: Write clear proposals presenting ideas and recommendations
examples: Problem statement, proposed solution, benefits, implementation plan, conclusion

name: Cohesion Advanced
description: Use sophisticated cohesive devices for text flow
examples: the former/latter, such, this phenomenon, these findings, as mentioned above

name: Register Shifts in Writing
description: Adapt writing register appropriately for different audiences and purposes
examples: Formal academic vs informal blog vs business email register

name: Participating in Debates
description: Participate in debates presenting and defending positions effectively
examples: Opening statement, rebuttal, questioning opponents, defending position

name: Giving Presentations with Data
description: Give presentations incorporating data, graphs, and visual aids effectively
examples: As you can see in this graph...
The data shows that...
This chart illustrates...

name: Expressing Nuanced Opinions
description: Express complex, nuanced opinions with qualifications and hedging
examples: To some extent...
It depends on...
While I agree in principle, ...
I'm inclined to think...

name: Persuading and Convincing
description: Persuade others using rhetorical devices and strong arguments
examples: Surely you must agree that...
The evidence clearly shows...
Consider the implications...

name: Negotiating
description: Negotiate effectively in professional and personal contexts
examples: How about if we...?
Would you be willing to...?
I can meet you halfway on...

name: Reading - Advanced Inference
description: Make complex inferences about implicit meaning, tone, purpose, bias
examples: What is the author's attitude?
What is implied but not stated?
What bias is present?

name: Reading - Evaluating Sources
description: Evaluate credibility, reliability, and bias of sources
examples: Is the source credible?
Is there evidence of bias?
Are claims supported?

name: Reading - Complex Structures
description: Understand texts with complex sentence structures and dense information
examples: Academic papers, legal documents, technical manuals

name: Listening - Lectures and Academic Talks
description: Understand lectures and academic talks on complex topics
examples: Follow arguments, understand terminology, identify key points in 20-30 minute lectures

name: Listening - Advanced Note-Taking
description: Take structured notes efficiently during complex listening tasks
examples: Cornell method, mind mapping, abbreviations, symbols for note-taking

name: Listening - Implicit Meaning
description: Understand implicit meaning, irony, sarcasm, and humor in speech
examples: Detect sarcasm, understand irony, recognize humor

name: Pronunciation - Advanced Features
description: Master advanced pronunciation features (elision, assimilation, intrusion)
examples: next door /neks dɔː/
handbag /hæmbæg/
go in /gəʊwɪn/

name: Pronunciation - Thought Groups
description: Divide speech into appropriate thought groups for clarity and meaning
examples: Yesterday // when I was walking home // I saw an accident

name: Fluency - Spontaneous Speech
description: Speak spontaneously with natural flow on wide range of topics
examples: Speak without preparation on unfamiliar topics with minimal hesitation

name: Strategic Competence
description: Use communication strategies effectively (paraphrasing, clarifying, confirming)
examples: In other words...
What I'm trying to say is...
Do you see what I mean?

name: Register Awareness in Speech
description: Adjust spoken register appropriately for different contexts and relationships
examples: Formal presentation vs informal chat vs professional meeting

name: Self-Correction Advanced
description: Self-correct effectively without disrupting communication flow
examples: I mean...
Or rather...
Actually...
